key_points: US COVID-19 cases are rising again, with new cases per day doubling over the past three weeks.
The rise is attributed to the delta variant, low vaccination rates, and Fourth of July gatherings.
Confirmed infections have climbed to an average of about 23,600 a day.
55.6% of all Americans have received at least one COVID-19 shot.
States with lower vaccination rates are seeing bigger jumps in cases.
Deaths remain lower than the peak in January, highlighting the vaccine's effectiveness.
Health authorities in some areas are urging even vaccinated people to wear masks again.
Mississippi and Louisiana, with low vaccination rates, are facing significant rises in cases.
There is resistance in some states to reintroducing restrictions or preventive measures.
President Biden is boosting vaccination efforts among young people with the help of celebrity Olivia Rodrigo.
spokespersons: Dr. Bill Powderly (Co-director, Infectious-Disease Division at Washington University's School of Medicine in St. Louis)
Dr. James Lawler (Leader, Global Center for Health Security at the University of Nebraska Medical Center in Omaha)
Erik Frederick (Chief Administrative Officer, Mercy Hospital Springfield)
